content.description: Climb up to a hanging flake which transitions to triple cracks before transitioning left to a final crack that leads to anchors on a ledge.
content.location:
Located between

Step Child

and

One More Mouth To Feed

.

content.description: This is the discontinuous crack system just right of Kindergarten Cop.  Follow the thin crack, past a horizontal, up and right to a nice hand crack.  Continue up the hand crack until it runs out, finishing up and left to the anchor for Kindergarten Cop.  The crux comes early and we felt the climb was easier than the 5.8 rating given in Hidden Treasures, with most of the climb going at 5.6.  A fun climb with great feet, good ledges and nice jams.  Rappel to descend.
Undercling up to the base of a right-slanting thin crack which dies out higher where interesting movement up the face finishes by pulling a bulge directly to the anchors.
content.protection:
Top-rope from anchors on

Kindergarten Cop
content.location:
In between

Kindergarten Cop

and

Step Child

.

content.description:
Climb up the good jam crack on the left side of the face that holds

Children Should Not Use Power Tools

.

Solid jams start the climb and you finish with good  flake holds.

Climb the wide crack immediately right of

Children Should Not Use Power Tools

with little trouble.
content.protection:
Trad Rack, anchors on

Children Should Not Use Power Tools

.

climbs.name: Kindergarten Cop
climbs.fa: Pete Paredes, Chris Miller & Lisa Guindon, September 2000

content.description:
Climb a short section of hand crack to a stance and the first bolt and then move onto the rounded arete face passing two more bolts via steep friction climbing to anchors on a small ledge.

The route is a little crunchy in spots but more traffic should help to clean it up nicely.
content.location:
Located on the left side of the east face about 25' left of

Children Should Not Use Power Tools

.

content.description:
Climb the right arete of the wall.   Struggle to stay left of the 1st bolt (if you stray right, the grade drops to 5.10b).

After the 1st bolt reach up and progress on sharp crimps until a rounded finish is encountered shortly after the 3rd bolt.

climbs.name: Children Should Not Use Power Tools

content.description:
This is the middle of three bolted routes on the east side and climbs a narrow face between two crack systems.

The crux comes early on as you pass the first bolt via a somewhat awkward mantel (easier slightly right), after which it's fun climbing up plates and edges to the anchors. Given 5.10b in the guidebook for the area, but it seems a bit easier.

So named by the first ascent party in response to the sport bolting of the nearby

Hungover Wall

, this was one of several early routes done that explored the possibilities of the Children's Forest area.

climbs.name: Child Proof
climbs.fa: Aidan Maguire, July 1990, First Lead Chris Miller, July 2000

content.description:
Climb up thin vertical seams, until a good notch for the right hand allows a high step up to the overhang and undercling.

After a breather at the undercling, move up using tip jams until the upper finishing crack is reached.

The anchors are reached easily after the wide hand crack.

Climb

Child Proof

to about the halfway point and then cut left into another crack/seam that leads to the top.
content.protection: Top-rope from bolted anchors on top.
content.location:
Just left of

Child Proof

on the right side of the rock.
